Award.AwardTitle: NYC Regional Math Alliance Conference at Kean University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for a one-day conference, The NYC Regional Math Alliance Conference, to be held at Kean University in New Jersey on September 15, 2018. The NYC Regional Math Alliance is an affiliate of the National Alliance for Doctoral Studies in the Mathematical Sciences (Math Alliance) that is focused on an effort to increase the number of students from underrepresented groups who obtain doctoral degrees in the mathematical sciences. The conference will highlight the research of students being mentored by the NYC Regional Math Alliance and will promote a continued interest in mathematics by fostering an atmosphere conducive to mathematical discussion and to the formulation and nurturing of new collaborations.

The conference will further the goal of increasing the numbers of students from underrepresented groups obtaining doctoral degrees in the mathematical sciences in several ways. On the one hand, the exposure of student participants to poster presentations and talks on mathematical research by their peers will heighten their interest in the subject. Meeting and interacting with faculty from PhD programs at nearby institutions presents the pursuit of a PhD as an accessible and realizable goal. Additionally, the conference will contribute to the building of a community of faculty interested in mentoring students from underrepresented groups. There are already a large number of faculty in the New Jersey and NYC area committed to the aims of the conference and this meeting will help organize and further their efforts. More details on the conference can be found on the webpage, http://mathalliance.ccny.cuny.edu/conference-2018/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NYC Regional Math Alliance Conference took place at Kean University on September 15, 2018. It was co-organized by Kean University in Union, NJ and the City College of New York. One of the major goals of the conference was to increase the number students, particularly those from underrepresented minorities, who are admitted to graduate school in the mathematical sciences. Attendance at the conference was 60, including 27 students. Special guests included the Executive Director of the National Alliance for Doctoral Studies in the Mathematical Sciences, the Dean of the College of Natural, Applied and Health Sciences at Kean University, the Chair of the Mathematics Department at CCNY, and a Special Assistant to the Mayor of New City (Bill De Blasio).

The conference featured two plenary talks, 8 talks in parallel sessions with participants giving 20-minute talks, and 8 poster presentations by students. Three faculty members, one graduate student, 14 undergraduate math majors, and 1 graduate student presented at the conference. The Executive Director of the National Alliance for Doctoral Studies in the Mathematical Sciences gave a plenary talk in the morning. A former Math Alliance student who is currently an Assistant Professor of mathematics at Purdue University participated on a panel on the graduate school admission process.

Following the conference, a survey of the participants showed results on fall 2019 acceptance in graduate school and 2019 REU summer programs. Roughly 30% of the student participants were accepted to doctoral programs in the mathematical sciences (19 % in doctoral programs and 11% in master’s programs). All the students accepted in doctoral programs were women, 4 (80%) of whom were from underrepresented groups in the STEM disciplines. Overall, the students were accepted in programs such as mathematics, public health, molecular medicine, biostatistics, educational measurement and statistics, and computer science. We also note that 4 (roughly 15%) were accepted and participated in Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) programs, with 3 students in mathematics and one in biostatistics. Three of the four students who participated in REU programs were underrepresented minority students.
